args.description: Usernames of the approvers.

args.description: Filter by release tag.

args.description: Array of IIDs of merge requests, for example `[1, 2]`.

args.description: Username of the merger.

args.name: myReactionEmoji
args.description: Filter by your reaction emoji.

args.name: or
args.description: List of arguments with inclusive OR.

args.name: sourceBranches
args.description:
Array of source branch names.
All resolved merge requests will have one of these branches as their source.

args.name: targetBranches
args.description:
Array of target branch names.
All resolved merge requests will have one of these branches as their target.

args.name: state
args.description: Merge request state. If provided, all resolved merge requests will have the state.

args.name: draft
args.description: Limit result to draft merge requests.

args.name: closedAfter
args.description: Merge requests closed after the date.

args.name: closedBefore
args.description: Merge requests closed before the date.

args.name: createdAfter
args.description: Merge requests created after the timestamp.

args.name: createdBefore
args.description: Merge requests created before the timestamp.

args.description: Merge requests deployed after the timestamp.

args.name: deployedBefore
args.description: Merge requests deployed before the timestamp.

args.description: ID of the deployment.

args.description: Environment merge requests have been deployed to.

args.description: Merge requests updated after the timestamp.

args.name: updatedBefore
args.description: Merge requests updated before the timestamp.

args.name: labelName
args.description: Labels applied to the merge request.

args.name: mergedAfter
args.description: Merge requests merged after the date.

args.name: mergedBefore
args.description: Merge requests merged before the date.

args.name: milestoneTitle
args.description: Title of the milestone. Incompatible with milestoneWildcardId.

args.name: milestoneWildcardId
args.description: Filter issues by milestone ID wildcard. Incompatible with milestoneTitle.

args.name: sort
args.description: Sort merge requests by the criteria.

args.name: subscribed
args.description: Merge requests the current user is subscribed to.

args.name: not
args.description:
List of negated arguments.
Warning: this argument is experimental and a subject to change in future.

args.name: groupId
args.description:
The global ID of the group the authored merge requests should be in.
Merge requests in subgroups are included.

args.name: projectPath

types.name: GlobalID
types.description:
A global identifier.

A global identifier represents an object uniquely across the application.
An example of a global identifier is `"gid://gitlab/User/1"`.

`gid://gitlab` stands for the root name.
`User` is the name of the ActiveRecord class of the record.
`1` is the record id as per the id in the db table.

Global identifiers are encoded as strings.

types.name: ID
types.description: Represents a unique identifier that is Base64 obfuscated. It is often used to refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable. When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"VXNlci0xMA=="`) or integer (such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.

fields.name: mergeRequestAccept
fields.description:
Accepts a merge request.
When accepted, the source branch will be scheduled to merge into the target branch, either
immediately if possible, or using one of the automatic merge strategies.

[In GitLab 16.5](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/421510), the merging happens asynchronously.
This results in `mergeRequest` and `state` not updating after a mutation request,
because the merging may not have happened yet.

args.description:
Specify the fields to perform the search in.

args.name: ids
args.description: Filter by global IDs of work items (maximum is 100 IDs).

args.name: authorUsername
args.description: Filter work items by author username.

args.name: confidential
args.description: Filter for confidential work items. If `false`, excludes confidential work items. If `true`, returns only confidential work items.

args.name: assigneeUsernames
args.description: Usernames of users assigned to the work item (maximum is 100 usernames).

args.name: assigneeWildcardId
args.description: Filter by assignee wildcard. Incompatible with `assigneeUsernames`.

args.name: labelName
args.description: Labels applied to the work item (maximum is 100 labels).

args.name: milestoneTitle
args.description: Milestone applied to the work item (maximum is 100 milestones).

args.name: milestoneWildcardId
args.description: Filter by milestone ID wildcard. Incompatible with `milestoneTitle`.

args.name: myReactionEmoji
args.description: Filter by reaction emoji applied by the current user. Wildcard values `NONE` and `ANY` are supported.

args.name: iids
args.description: List of IIDs of work items. For example, `["1", "2"]` (maximum is 100 IIDs).

args.description: Current state of the work item.

args.name: types
args.description: Filter work items by the given work item types.

args.description: Work items created before the timestamp.

args.description: Negated work item arguments.

args.description: List of arguments with inclusive `OR`.

args.name: releaseTagWildcardId

types.name: PackagesProtectionRule
types.description: A packages protection rule designed to protect packages from being pushed by users with a certain access level.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Global ID of the package protection rule.

fields.name: minimumAccessLevelForDelete
fields.description: Minimum GitLab access required to delete packages from the package registry. Valid values include `OWNER` or `ADMIN`. If the value is `nil`, the default minimum access level is `MAINTAINER`. Available only when feature flag `packages_protected_packages_delete` is enabled. Introduced in GitLab 17.10: **Status**: Experiment.

fields.name: minimumAccessLevelForPush
fields.description: Minimum GitLab access required to push packages to the package registry. Valid values include `MAINTAINER`, `OWNER`, or `ADMIN`. If the value is `nil`, the default minimum access level is `DEVELOPER`.

fields.name: packageNamePattern
fields.description: Package name protected by the protection rule. For example, `@my-scope/my-package-*`. Wildcard character `*` allowed.

fields.name: packageType
fields.description: Package type protected by the protection rule. For example, `NPM`, `PYPI`.

Defaults to `[TITLE, DESCRIPTION]`. Requires the `search` argument.'

args.name: approvedBy

args.name: ids

args.name: or

args.name: releaseTag

A `UserID` is a global ID. It is encoded as a string.

types.name: UserMergeRequestInteraction
types.description:
Information about a merge request given a specific user.

This object has two parts to its state: a `User` and a `MergeRequest`. All
fields relate to interactions between the two entities.

types.name: WorkItemID
types.description:
A `WorkItemID` is a global ID. It is encoded as a string.

An example `WorkItemID` is: `"gid://gitlab/WorkItem/1"`.

While we transition from Issues into Work Items this type will temporarily support
`IssueID` like: `"gid://gitlab/Issue/1"`. This behavior will be removed without notice in the future.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name and description, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.
